Headline.Para: Austin Bombing Suspect: Home-Schooled College Dropout Known for Dry Wit; Stunned family members say they saw no signs of violent behavior

LeadPara.Para: PFLUGERVILLE, Texas—Mark Anthony Conditt, the man authorities say carried out a string of bombing attacks in Austin, was a home-schooled 23-year-old who had dropped out of college and lived in a fast-growing bedroom community north of Austin.

Mr. Conditt, who blew himself up after a showdown with police Wednesday morning, stood out for his intelligence, people who knew him said. He had once parried with classmates in a college class through blog posts, voicing his opposition to same-sex marriage, among other issues. He liked tennis, cycling and music, he wrote.

TailParas.Para: Stunned family members and friends said they saw no signs of
the reign of violence he would unleash on the Austin area this month, mailing and setting off package bombs that killed two people and wounded several more.
"We had no idea of the darkness that Mark must have been in," said his aunt, Shanee Courtney, adding, "For him to flip like this is extraordinary. I'm sorry we couldn't have seen it."
Ms. Courtney, who lives in Colorado and hosted the Conditt family over Christmas, described her nephew as the life of the party, who had a dry wit and said funny things when the family played cards.
The suspect's parents were roused by Federal Bureau of Investigation agents at 3:30 a.m. Wednesday, Ms. Courtney said.
Law-enforcement officials went through Mr. Conditt's home Wednesday and found significant bomb-making materials including components and homemade explosives, but no completed devices.

Austin Police Chief Brian Manley said Mr. Conditt left a 25-minute "confession" on his cell phone. "It is the outcry of a very challenged young man talking about challenges in his life," he said at a press conference. He said Mr Conditt didn't mention terrorism or hate and described seven bombs, all of which law-enforcement officials have accounted for.
"They are just broken and hurting," Ms. Courtney said.
Mike Courtney, Ms. Courtney's husband, said he knew Mark as intelligent and "just a normal kid."
Mr. Conditt, the oldest of four with three sisters, had been working with his father to restore and resell a home in Texas, said
"I have no idea where this came from, we have no idea where this came from," said Mr. Courtney.

A longtime friend of the family said the news was shocking. The friend, who last saw Mr. Conditt several years ago, said Mr. Conditt's parents are trained engineers who had decided to home-school their children.
"They're a very normal family, very all-American, salt of the earth people," she said. "Oh, my God, I'm just shocked."
Police said they homed in on Mr. Conditt as a person of interest earlier this week and by late Tuesday felt confident that he was responsible for the string of attacks that jolted Austin residents.
His vehicle was tracked to a hotel in a town about 20 miles north of Austin where he detonated an explosive device, killing himself in a confrontation with law enforcement.

The suspect's mother, Danene Conditt, said in a 2013 Facebook post that she officially graduated him from high school. She mentioned that he had 30 hours of college credit, "but he's thinking of taking some time to figure out what he wants to do…maybe a mission trip," she wrote.
The post included a picture of Mr. Conditt, smiling and wearing a dark-colored polo shirt.
Neither of the suspect's parents could be reached for comment.

Austin Community College confirmed that Mark Conditt was a student there from 2010 to 2012 and majored in business administration. He took general-education classes at two different campuses, the school said. He didn't graduate but left the school in good academic standing.

In a blogger.com profile that was part of a college government course, Mark Conditt described himself as conservative but not politically inclined, and needing more information to defend his stance. In a string of lengthy 2012 blog posts under the heading "defining my stance," he argued against same-sex marriage and free abortions, while supporting the death penalty and the concept of doing away with sex-offender registries. He also agreed with a newspaper column arguing against releasing a captured terrorist.

In response to another classmate's post defending same-sex marriage, Mr. Conditt wrote that homosexuality wasn't natural, and that people of the same sex weren't designed to couple. He equated passing laws supporting gay rights with laws that would protect pedophilia and bestiality.

Mr. Conditt had been living in Pflugerville, a city of about 60,000 people that has been absorbed by Austin's sprawling suburbs. An address recently associated with Mr. Conditt was located on a dead-end road near Pflugerville's historic downtown.
Law enforcement officers—Texas Department of Public Safety troopers and Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives agents—blocked off access to the house Wednesday.
Local residents were shocked that the bomber came from their community.
Darla Roessler, a neighbor of Conditt's, described him as a nice young man to whom she gave an entertainment center when he moved into the house on 2nd Street.
"Polite young man, very appreciative of the furniture," she said. Now she's questioning: "What changed in between those days and the last month for this young man?"

Ms. Roessler said she hates to think her otherwise quiet neighbor is the Austin bomber. But the FBI visited her house. She recalled hearing one of the visitors ask her husband, "Do you think you can sketch a basic floor plan for SWAT before they go in?" So her husband did.
The episode has left her conflicted. "Even though I know he did this horrendous thing," she said, "he too had family who loved him."
Mark Roessler said he and his wife were getting ready for work around 6:20 a.m. when they noticed their neighborhood on a newscast about the bomber.
When Mr. Roessler stepped outside, he said he saw a number of FBI agents and quickly found himself at gunpoint.
"At that moment in time it's kind of hard to process what's going on," he said. "It's so surreal."
Mr. Roessler said he was questioned, then told to stay inside. He would later draw a sketch of his neighbor's house for authorities.
He said he met Mr. Conditt and his father when the two spent a year working on Mr. Conditt's house. He said he felt the father was trying to bond with his son.
Lisa Schwartz contributed to this article.
Write to Erin Ailworth at Erin.Ailworth@wsj.com, Scott Calvert at scott.calvert@wsj.com and Jon Kamp at jon.kamp@wsj.com
